{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3557233,"name":"","username":"Whatisthie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/8491ac/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T19:50:07.444Z","cooked":"

Hello there I have been working on making our motor move up and down at the press of a key in java. here’s a sample of what i want the code to do
public void teleopPeriodic() {
CommandXboxController exampleCommandController = new CommandXboxController(1); // Creates a CommandXboxController on port 1.
Trigger xButton = exampleCommandController.x(); // Creates a new Trigger object for the X button on exampleCommandController
SparkMax Arm_Motor = new SparkMax(1,MotorType.kBrushless);
double WhereAmI = Arm_Motor.getEncoder().getPosition();
//below is the psuedocode blueprint for a function to create a adjustable shooter.
/**button1 = Xboxcontroller bind
if keydown button1 = true ()
button1 value = button1 + 1
else:
button1 value = button 1 + 0

button2 = XboxController bind
if keydown button2 = true
button 2 value = button2 - 1
else:
button2 value = button2 + 0
**
}
so if somebody could provide me with a idea of how to put this psuedocode blueprint into actual java code that could be functional

I’m not entirely sure if it’s what you are looking for, but something like this works in Java?

xButton.onTrue(new InstantCommand(() -> { subsystem.setMotorSpeed(value); });
xButton.onFalse(new InstantCommand(() -> { subsystem.stopMotor(value); });

You can substitute anything inside of the InstantCommand with what you need to perform. It would cause that action to only happen while the X button is being pressed.

Alternatively, you should be able to use xButton.GetAsBoolean() in your if statement to branch your logic to see when the button is pressed or not.

I can be a bit more precise if you can explain a bit more about what you are trying to accomplish. The pseudo code isn’t clear to follow with the different references/buttons/values on what you are trying to accomplish in the end? it seems like maybe increasing/decreasing a setpoint value for an encoder?

Jreed129:

it seems like maybe increasing/decreasing a setpoint value for an encoder?

Following up on this example, I remembered we actualy do this in some of our code. using the same thing above, we just call this method in our subsystem and provide it a value (positive or negative) for direction we want the motor to go.

public void setPosition(double positionIncrease) {
    var leftIncrease = this._coralLeftSparkMax.getEncoder().getPosition() + positionIncrease;
    this._coralLeftSparkMax.getEncoder().setPosition(leftIncrease);
    
    var rightIncrease = this._coralRightSparkMax.getEncoder().getPosition() + positionIncrease;
    this._coralRightSparkMax.getEncoder().setPosition(rightIncrease);
  }
